articles.summary: President Donald Trump is visiting hurricane-hit western North Carolina and wildfire-ravaged Los Angeles on Friday. articles.title: Western North Carolina saw one of its hottest years ever recorded in 2024
articles.author: Bpr News
articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest year on record for Asheville, Macon, Jackson, Clay, Madison, Yancey, Mitchell, Ashe, Alleghany, Surry, and Avery counties all saw their hottest years on record. There have been increased cycles of drought and extreme rain across the state. In Buncombe County, Asheville saw record lengths of time without snow, as well as its third wettest year.

articles.title: Stakeholders advocate robust solutions to gender, climate resilience
articles.author: Tina Abeku
articles.summary: Stakeholders at the sixth Nigeria Academy of Science Annual Scientific Conference have called for the use of credible data in addressing the gender and intersectional dimensions of climate change. Deputy Clerk of the House of Representatives, Vivian Njemanze, said research is essential to support the action of government.

articles.title: NDMA participates at RCC forum in Thailand
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: NDMA Pakistan's delegation participated in the 18th meeting of the Regional Consultative Committee (RCC) in Bangkok, Thailand on Thursday. The theme of this year's RCC meeting is "Sustainable Anticipatory Actions for Resilient Development Goals". In his keynote speech, Chairman NDMA Lt. Gen Inam Haider Malik highlighted the impacts of climate change in the Asia-Pacific Region and in Pakistan.

articles.title: Rising temperatures, rising anxiety
articles.summary: Climate change is an undeniable and pressing global crisis. It is affecting not only the environment but also the psychological well-being of individuals and entire communities. The average temperature in Bangladesh has risen by 0.5 degrees Celsius since 1991. More than 7 million people in Bangladesh have been displaced due to the effects of climate change, many of whom struggle with psychological issues in the aftermath.

articles.title: Canada Boosts Climate Adaptation for Safer Communities
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Natural Resources Canada announced $4.5 million in funding for nine projects in southern Ontario and across Canada. The projects aim to enhance knowledge and skills among professionals, businesses and communities to adapt to a changing climate. The funding comes from a total investment of $39 million announced on November 14, 2024.

articles.title: Poll claims almost half the world's population, 20% of Australians antisemitic
articles.author: Kim Wingerei
articles.summary: According to the ADL survey, anti-Jewish sentiments are at an all-time high globally and 4.7 million Australians are antisemites. The survey was conducted by the US-based Jewish lobby group, the Anti-Defamation League (ADL). It polled 58,000 people in 103 nations and came to the conclusion that 46% of the world's population holds deeply entrenched antisemitic views.

articles.title: Climate shocks in 2024 disrupted 242 million children's schooling: UNICEF
articles.author: AFP-Jiji
articles.summary: Extreme weather disrupted the schooling of about 242 million children in 85 countries last year. Children are more vulnerable to extreme weather because they heat up faster, sweat less efficiently and cool down more slowly than adults, according to UNICEF's executive director Catherine Russell. The agency deplores this aspect of the climate crisis.

articles.title: Lower North Dakota waterfowl numbers in midwinter survey not a surprise, Game and Fish says
articles.author: Grand Forks Herald
articles.summary: There were 88,000 Canada geese and 3,225 mallards in North Dakota during the midwinter waterfowl survey. Cold temperatures in November and early January pushed many birds south. Lake Sakakawea froze over on Jan. 4, two days before the survey.

articles.title: Winter Drought
articles.summary: Pakistan's vulnerability to climate change is not confined to specific seasons or isolated weather events, but affects the nation year-round. This year, a prolonged winter drought has left vast stretches of Punjab parched, significantly reducing agricultural production. Agriculture contributes nearly a quarter of Pakistan's GDP and employs 37% of its labor force. The stress on the Indus River and its tributaries continues to grow under the pressures of a burgeoning population and excessive demands on already scarce water resources. Pakistan can't afford to treat its water resources carelessly, so the focus must shift to preserving these resources for long-term national and societal stability.

articles.title: Pakistan, Asia-Pacific region: NDMA chief underscores profound impacts of climate change
articles.author: Recorder Report
articles.summary: Lt Gen Inam Haider Malik is the Chairman of Pakistan's National Disaster Management Authority. He was speaking at the 18th meeting of the Regional Consultative Committee (RCC) in Bangkok, Thailand. The RCC promotes regional collaboration in reducing disaster and climate change risks across Asia and the Pacific.

articles.title: Great Lakes ice coverage skyrockets amid cold snap
articles.author: Dennis Mersereau
articles.summary: The recent cold snap has increased the amount of surface ice on the Great Lakes. About 23.2 percent of the lakes were covered by ice as of Thursday, Jan. 23. This is just shy of the region's normal ice coverage of about 24 percent. Lake Erie saw the biggest increase in ice coverage out of the five lakes.

articles.title: YOUR SAY: Too much disinformation about climate change
articles.summary: Greg Pullen is right to say that we need a shocking event like the recent LA wildfires to understand the climate risks we now face. The ongoing climate disinformation campaign by the global fossil fuel industry and other climate polluters has deliberately slowed the necessary climate policies. Peter Dutton has drawn equal in the preferred PM stakes with Albo. Australia Day is less than a week away.

articles.title: Zim, Australia to upgrade ties
articles.author: The Herald
articles.summary: Prof Amon Murwira wants to see the revival of direct flights between the two countries. Qantas, Australia's flagship airline, stopped operating in Zimbabwe in March 1998. Prof Mur wira also highlighted the importance of agricultural collaboration in light of climate change challenges. Ambassador Minoli Tehani Perera commended Zimbabwe for abolishing the death penalty.

articles.title: Yesterdate: This day from Kolkata's past, January 24, 1898
articles.author: Chandrima S. Bhattacharya
articles.summary: The Sydney Morning Herald published a report titled 'Calcutta Two Thousand Years Hence' that spoke about climate change. It predicted a cooling of the northern hemisphere. The number of summer days in the northern Hemisphere is now about eight in excess of the number in the southern.

articles.title: Farmer Focus: Climate change is affecting farm output
articles.author: Dafydd Parry Jones
articles.summary: There is a growing concern about the impact of climate change on farmers' farms. The frequency of drought is increasing across the UK. Growing red and white clover at home reduces the amount of imported concentrates and lowers production costs. Organic farming means zero use of inorganic fertilisers and chemicals and planting over 20,000 trees.

articles.title: Conservationists call for people to join annual Big Garden Birdwatch
articles.author: Viral News
articles.summary: The RSPB's Big Garden Birdwatch is taking place this weekend. It's the world's largest garden wildlife survey to see how birds are faring across the UK. The recent cold snap could have affected birds, particularly smaller species such as wrens and long-tailed tits. House sparrows have seen their count in gardens drop by 60% over the years.

articles.title: Climate Change, Thailand Style
articles.author: Mark Lewis
articles.summary: This winter Thailand has had the coldest weather since I've been here. To the Left, this is a sign of 'global warming' and a sign that man and technology are having an effect on earth's climate. Thomas Jefferson said in 1799 that snows are less frequent and less deep. The 18th century was a warmer century, coming out of the 'Little Ice Age' in the mid-second millennium, which followed the Medieval Warming Period.

articles.title: Conservationists call for people to join annual Big Garden Birdwatch

articles.summary: The RSPB's Big Garden Birdwatch is taking place this weekend. People will spend an hour counting the birds they see in their garden, balcony, local park or other green space. The recent cold snap could have affected birds, particularly smaller species such as wrens and long-tailed tits. Many garden birds are in decline. House sparrows have seen their count in gardens drop by a'staggering' 60%.

articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: A series investigating the country's vast environmental inequalities and how climate change will make things worse. It's called "The End of the Landscape" and it's on CNN.com/TheEnd of The Landscape. It will be a series about environmental inequality and climate change.

articles.summary: The rise in extreme weather is not generating political support for climate action, according to Germany's best-known climate activist. He bought into the idea that big catastrophes would do something to politics, because he believed they would bring about change.

articles.summary: The costs of extreme weather events like the Los Angeles wildfires pile up, but the US federal policy pendulum is swinging away from facts, reason and basic human decency. The US government is moving in the opposite direction. Gernot Wagner is not optimistic about the climate.

The iceberg was previously "trapped" spinning around an undersea mountain for several months. It is currently in a meander of the current and not moving directly towards the Island.

articles.summary: Planned drone shows to celebrate Australia Day in the nation's capital have had their start time pushed back to prevent harm to a population of threatened bats. The population of about 2,500 grey-headed flying foxes is listed as vulnerable to extinction by the federal government.

articles.title: Letter: Extreme events increasing, both in frequency, intensity
articles.summary: Scientists say 2024 will be the hottest year on record due to human-caused climate change. Wildfires are burning hotter and moving faster. Storms are getting bigger and carrying more moisture. Heat waves and drought killed thousands of people last year and displaced millions in Europe and the U.S.

articles.title: Staying together
articles.summary: A group of Canada geese were gathered on the frozen water of the Ohio River near New Cumberland Thursday afternoon. Temperatures are beginning to rise following the effects of the polar vortex on the area earlier this week. They are expected to remain below freezing for the next few days, cresting toward mid 30s by Wednesday.
